== Developing custom Gradle plug-ins
=== Why creating Gradle plug-ins As a general rule, it is useful to have a build that is as much declarative as possible as this simplifies future maintenance. Therefore it is adviced to avoid complex code in your Gradle build file. If you need customer logic you should place it, into a custom Gradle plugin.
=== Example: creating a simple Gradle plugin
To create a custom Gradle plug-in you have to create the following directories for your Gradle project. The java or groovy directory is only required if you want to use Java or Groovy for writing your plugin.
* projectroot/plugin/src/main/java
* projectroot/plugin/src/main/resources/META-INF/gradle-plugins
* projectroot/plugin/src/main/groovy
Change your main _build.gradle_ build file to the following. [source,java] ----- include::res/plugin/mainbuild.gradle[] ----
Create a file _vogella.properties_
in the _META-INF/gradle-plugins_ folder. The name of the properties file defines your plugin name and its content points to the class which implements the plugin. [source,java] ----- include::res/plugin/vogella.properties[] ----
In the _plugin/src/main/java_ folder create the following two classes. [source,java] ----- include::res/plugin/MyPlugin.java[] ---- [source,java] ----- include::res/plugin/MyTask.java[] ----
In your _plugin_ folder, create the following build.gradle file. [source,java] ----- include::res/plugin/build.gradle[] ----
In your _plugin_ folder, create the following _settings.gradle_ file. [source,java] ----- include::res/plugin/settings.gradle[] ----
=== Example: deploy your custom Gradle plug-in to your local Maven repository Publish your Gradle plug-in to the Maven repo defined in your plugin/build.gradle file via the following command. [source,java] ----- include::res/plugin/publish.gradle[] ----
